info.game_comments:
2005 College Championship quarterfinal game 3.
From the RBC Center in Raleigh, North Carolina.

(3, 1).clue: In American slang, to get rid of something by throwing it overboard is to give it this kind of six

(4, 1).clue: A "College" for these silly circus performers opened in 1968 (& no, I am not a graduate)

(5, 1).clue: This company's first podcast talked about its new Cadillacs at the Chicago Auto Show

(6, 1).clue: Pluma can be either a pen or one of these, as from a swan

(3, 2).clue: His Sixth Symphony was termed the "Pastoral"

(4, 2).clue: Located in Saskatoon, the University of this Canadian province is set for its centennial in 2007

(5, 2).clue: A morning stock report is podcast by this Dow Jones-owned national newspaper

(6, 2).clue: 4-letter English translation of the Spanish un laberinto

(1, 3).clue: 37-41 A.D.:Nutty guy who once "declared war" against the ocean

(2, 3).clue: How a Brit & a Yank might each try to spell labor, humor, valor...

(3, 3).clue: This group was originally made up of 6 members; in 1869 Congress changed its total to 9

(4, 3).clue: On an alphabetical list of the colleges known as the Seven Sisters, this Manhattan school comes first

(5, 3).clue: We aren't sure if the podcasts for this Sci Fi Channel show are created by humans or Cylons

(6, 3).clue: To a Spaniard or a Spanish-speaking Eskimo, this creature is an oso blanco

(1, 4).clue: 306-337 A.D.:Converted to a non-Roman religion & moved the capital city

(2, 4).clue: It describes the location seen here

(3, 4).clue: It's the horticultural name for the sixth Sunday in Lent

(4, 4).clue: This Vermont school chartered in 1925 boasts that its graduates have resumes as well as diplomas

(5, 4).clue: The podcast by this company discussed the promise of "on demand" with its new mainframes

(6, 4).clue: From the Spanish for "village", it's a collective name for Indian tribes like the Hopi & Zuni

(1, 5).clue: 27 B.C.-14 A.D.:His sister married Mark Antony & he defeated Mark Antony

(3, 5).clue: Any solid figure having 6 faces; a cube, for example

(4, 5).clue: The second "S" in LSUS stands for this city

(5, 5).clue: No joke, this satellite radio company signed former MTV-VJ Adam Curry as its exclusive PJ

(6, 5).clue: The name of this line dance comes from Spanish & refers to a country in Africa

(1, 1).clue: In 1603 Sir Walter Raleigh was tried & convicted of this for plotting to dethrone the king

(2, 1).clue: Owen Wilson & Vince Vaughn are divorce mediators in this film

(3, 1).clue: Scout Finch lives with dad Atticus & brother Jem in Maycomb, Alabama in this classic novel

(4, 1).clue: Wolf Blitzer was born in this New York city that's home to some Bills, Sabres & Wings

(5, 1).clue: Mercury flights had 1 astronaut, Apollo had 3; this intermediate program had 2-man flights

(6, 1).clue: A common type of pet turtle, or the type of structure you might keep it in

(1, 2).clue: Raleigh introduced this tuber into Ireland; seemed like a good idea at the time

(4, 2).clue: Prior to the 2000 elections, Wolf hosted a town hall meeting with this First Lady & Senate hopeful

(5, 2).clue: William Hale's 1844 military rocket, using curved vanes, stayed stable by doing this in flight

(6, 2).clue: At Parris Island, Marines learn techniques for using this rifle blade

(1, 3).clue: In 1569 Raleigh fought in France on the side of these French Protestants

(2, 3).clue: This 2004 film is about photographer Julia Roberts & bedmates

(3, 3).clue: The title of this novel refers to "a small log building, close adjoining to 'The House'... his master's dwelling"

(4, 3).clue: Blitzer started his career in 1972 with this huge news service named for the German who started it in 1851

(5, 3).clue: In Dec. 1972 Gene Cernan became the last man to command one of these vehicles known as the LM

(6, 3).clue: A ring-shaped cake pan with fluted sides

(1, 4).clue: A poet himself, Raleigh encouraged this man to publish "The Faerie Queene"

(2, 4).clue: At the end of "Collateral", Tom Cruise says, "I do this for a living"

(3, 4).clue: Oprah's Book Club read Faulkner's "As I Lay Dying", "The Sound & the Fury" & this aptly titled one in summer 2005

(4, 4).clue: In 2003 Wolf won an award named for this reporter slain in Pakistan by terrorists in 2002

(5, 4).clue: (Jon of the Clue Crew releases a balloon.)  Thrust comes from the sudden inequality of this, sometimes measured in atmospheres, inside & outside a rocket

(6, 4).clue: A strong, coarsely woven cloth made from jute or hemp

(1, 5).clue: In 1600 Raleigh was appointed governor of Jersey, part of this island group

(2, 5).clue: Nicole Kidman speaks fluent Ku as this 2005 title character

(3, 5).clue: This Chicago-set Richard Wright novel centers on Bigger Thomas, who ends up killing his own sweetheart

(4, 5).clue: In 1991 Wolf returned to Moscow to cover this new Russian president

(5, 5).clue: To leave Earth's orbit, a rocket must accelerate to 25,000 mph to achieve this, EV for short

(6, 5).clue: This Slovak capital was also known by the German name of Pressburg

(0, 0).clue: 5 state capitals, all of them on or west of the Mississippi, begin with these 2 letters
